new.doc: Creates a new App instance from the given `AppConfig`

fn_args.doc: The initialized data model of the application, will be passed to the `LayoutCallback` of the active windows
Additional configuration on how the global application should behave

add_window.doc: Spawn a new window on the screen when the app is run.

fn_args.doc: New window, note that this will **not** be spawned as the root window

get_monitors.doc: Returns a list of monitors - useful for setting the monitor that a window should spawn on.

returns.doc: List of currently attached monitors, note that this `Vec` will be empty on wasm32

run.doc: Runs the application. Due to platform restrictions (specifically `WinMain` on Windows), this function never returns.

fn_args.doc: Initial state of the root (main) window of the application

AppConfig.doc: Configuration for optional features, such as whether to enable logging or panic hooks

layout_solver.doc: Which layout solver version to use, necessary so that future upgrades don't break the layout of old programs

log_level.doc: If enabled, logs error and info messages

enable_visual_panic_hook.doc: If the app crashes / panics, a window with a message box pops up

enable_logging_on_panic.doc: If set, a backtrace + error information gets logged to stdout (if the log_level is not `LogLevel::Off`)

enable_tab_navigation.doc: Whether keyboard navigation should be enabled

system_callbacks.doc: External callbacks to create a thread or get the curent time

AppLogLevel.doc: Configuration to set which messages should be logged.

LayoutSolverVersion.doc: Version of the layout solver to use - future binary versions of azul may have more fields here, necessary so that old compiled applications don't break with newer releases of azul. Newer layout versions are opt-in only.

SystemCallbacks.doc: External system callbacks to get the system time or create / manage threads

library_internal.doc: Use the default, library-internal callbacks instead of providing your own

WindowCreateOptions.doc: Options on how to initially create the window

state.doc: Initial state of the window on the first frame

renderer_type.doc: If not `None`, azul will try to create a window with the specific renderer type and **crash** if the renderer is not available for whatever reason

theme.doc: Initially the `theme` on the `WindowState` is set to the OS theme - use this field to override the operating systems `Dark` or `Light` mode

create_callback.doc: Callback to run **once** when the window is initially created

hot_reload.doc: If set to true, will hot-reload the UI every 200ms. Default: false

new.doc: Creates a new window configuration with a custom layout callback

fn_args.doc: The callback to call when the UI of the window should be rendered

RendererOptions.doc: Force a specific renderer: note that azul will **crash** on startup if the `RendererOptions` are not satisfied.

vsync.doc: Force the renderer to enable VSync. Set this only if your application can't run without VSync.

srgb.doc: Force the renderer to enable SRGB (OpenGL extension). Set this only if your application can't run without correct SRGB handling and color correctness is a priority.

hw_accel.doc: Force the renderer to enable hardware acceleration. Set this only if your application can't run without hardware acceleration (ex. for games).

Vsync.doc: Whether the renderer has VSync enabled

Srgb.doc: Does the renderer render in SRGB color space? By default, azul tries to set it to `Enabled` and falls back to `Disabled` if the OpenGL context can't be initialized properly

HwAcceleration.doc: Does the renderer render using hardware acceleration? By default, azul tries to set it to `Enabled` and falls back to `Disabled` if the OpenGL context can't be initialized properly

LayoutRect.doc: Represents a rectangle in physical pixels (integer units)

RawWindowHandle.doc: Raw platform handle, for integration in / with other toolkits and custom non-azul window extensions

connection.doc: A pointer to an X server `xcb_connection_t`

hinstance.doc: Pointer to a `HINSTANCE` associated with this windows `HWND`.

id.doc: An ID value inserted into the data attributes of the canvas element. Set to 0 if invalid.

XWindowType.doc: X11 window hint: Type of window

Desktop.doc: A desktop feature. This can include a single window containing desktop icons with the same dimensions as the screen, allowing the desktop environment to have full control of the desktop, without the need for proxying root window clicks

Dock.doc: A dock or panel feature. Typically a Window Manager would keep such windows on top of all other windows

Toolbar.doc: Toolbar windows. "Torn off" from the main application

Menu.doc: Pinnable menu windows. "Torn off" from the main application

Utility.doc: A small persistent utility window, such as a palette or toolbox

Splash.doc: The window is a splash screen displayed as an application is starting up

DropdownMenu.doc: A dropdown menu that usually appears when the user clicks on an item in a menu bar. This property is typically used on override-redirect windows.

PopupMenu.doc: A popup menu that usually appears when the user right clicks on an object. This property is typically used on override-redirect windows.

Tooltip.doc: A tooltip window. Usually used to show additional information when hovering over an object with the cursor. This property is typically used on override-redirect windows.

Notification.doc: The window is a notification. This property is typically used on override-redirect windows.

Combo.doc: This should be used on the windows that are popped up by combo boxes. This property is typically used on override-redirect windows.

Dnd.doc: This indicates the the window is being dragged. This property is typically used on override-redirect windows.

Normal.doc: This is a normal, top-level window

PhysicalPositionI32.doc: Same as `LayoutPoint`, but uses `i32` instead of `isize`

PhysicalSizeU32.doc: Same as `LayoutPoint`, but uses `u32` instead of `isize`

LogicalRect.doc: Logical rectangle area (can differ based on HiDPI settings). Usually this is what you'd want for hit-testing and positioning elements.

LogicalPosition.doc: Logical position (can differ based on HiDPI settings). Usually this is what you'd want for hit-testing and positioning elements.

LogicalSize.doc: A size in "logical" (non-HiDPI-adjusted) pixels in floating-point units

IconKey.doc: Unique hash of a window icon, so that azul does not have to compare the actual bytes to see wether the window icon has changed.

id.doc: Can be any number, just has to be unique to the application. You need to generate a new `IconKey` if the window icon of your application has changed.

SmallWindowIconBytes.doc: Small (16x16x4) window icon, usually shown in the window titlebar

key.doc: Key / hash of the window icon, so that azul can detect whether the icon has changed and notify the OS about the change.

rgba_bytes.doc: Decoded bytes of the window icon, [32x32x4] bytes in length, rgba format

LargeWindowIconBytes.doc: Large (32x32x4) window icon, usually used on high-resolution displays (instead of `SmallWindowIcon`)

key.doc: Key / hash of the taskbar icon, so that azul can detect whether the icon has changed and notify the OS about the change.

rgba_bytes.doc: Decoded bytes of the window icon, [32x32x4] bytes in length, rgba format

WindowIcon.doc: Window "favicon", usually shown in the top left of the window on Windows

TaskBarIcon.doc: Application taskbar icon, 256x256x4 bytes in size

key.doc: Unique icon key so that azul can determine whether the application icon has changed and notify the OS about the change

rgba_bytes.doc: Decoded bytes of the taskbar icon, 256x256x4 bytes in size, rgba format

VirtualKeyCode.doc: Symbolic name for a keyboard key, does **not** take the keyboard locale into account

WindowSize.doc: Minimum / maximum / current size of the window in logical dimensions

hidpi_factor.doc: HiDPI factor that can be overridden by the application

system_hidpi_factor.doc: HiDPI factor of the system - note that some systems report the scaling factor wrong (esp. Linux HiDPI). Usually the same as `hidpi_factor`.

min_dimensions.doc: Maximum size of the window in logical units

max_dimensions.doc: Minimum size of the window in logical units

WindowFlags.doc: Boolean flags relating to the current window state

is_about_to_close.doc: Is the window about to close on the next frame? Setting this to true will close the window.

has_decorations.doc: Does the window have decorations (close, minimize, maximize, title bar)?

is_always_on_top.doc: Is the window always on top?

has_focus.doc: Whether the window is currently focused (changing this field will request user attention)

has_extended_window_frame.doc: Whether the window has an "extended frame", i.e. the title bar is not rendered and the maximize / minimize / close buttons bleed into the window content

has_blur_behind_window.doc: Whether the window has a background blur

DebugState.doc: Debugging information, will be rendered as an overlay on top of the UI

profiler_dbg.doc: Display the frame profiler on screen

render_target_dbg.doc: Display intermediate render targets on screen

texture_cache_dbg.doc: Display all texture cache pages on screen

gpu_sample_queries.doc: Query the number of pixels that pass the depth test divided and show it in the profiler as a percentage of the number of pixels in the screen (window width times height)

disable_batching.doc:
Render each quad with their own draw call.
Terrible for performance but can help with understanding the drawing order when inspecting renderdoc or apitrace recordings

show_overdraw.doc: Show an overlay displaying overdraw amount

gpu_cache_dbg.doc: Display the contents of GPU cache

texture_cache_dbg_clear_evicted.doc: Clear evicted parts of the texture cache for debugging purposes

primitive_dbg.doc: Highlight all primitives with colors based on kind

zoom_dbg.doc: Draw a zoom widget showing part of the framebuffer zoomed in

small_screen.doc: Scale the debug renderer down for a smaller screen. This will disrupt any mapping between debug display items and page content, so shouldn't be used with overlays like the picture caching or primitive display

disable_opaque_pass.doc: Disable various bits of the WebRender pipeline, to help narrow down where slowness might be coming from

glyph_flashing.doc: Taint the transparent area of the glyphs with a random opacity to easily see when glyphs are re-rasterized

smart_profiler.doc: The profiler only displays information that is out of the ordinary

invalidation_dbg.doc: Dump picture cache invalidation information to stdout

tile_cache_logging_dbg.doc: Print debug information about tile caches

profiler_capture.doc: Capture a profile of the frame to a file

force_picture_invalidation.doc: Force WebRender to render a new frame, even if WR can't determine that the display has changed

KeyboardState.doc: Current keyboard state, stores what keys / characters have been pressed

shift_down.doc: Tracks if the `Shift` key is currently pressed - (READONLY)

ctrl_down.doc: Tracks if the `Ctrl` key is currently pressed - (READONLY)

alt_down.doc: Tracks if the `Alt` key is currently pressed - (READONLY)

super_down.doc: Tracks if the `Super / Windows / Command` key is currently pressed - (READONLY)

current_virtual_keycode.doc: Currently pressed `VirtualKeyCode` - (READONLY). **DO NOT USE THIS FOR TEXT INPUT, USE `current_char` and `On::TextInput` instead.**

pressed_virtual_keycodes.doc: List of currently held-down `VirtualKeyCodes` - useful to implement combinated shortcuts (ex. `Ctrl + Shift + Right`)

pressed_scancodes.doc: List of currently held-down `ScanCode`s (typedef for `u32`). Same as `current_virtual_keycodes`, but the scancode identifies the physical key pressed, independent of the keyboard layout. The scancode does not change if the user adjusts the host's keyboard map. Use when the physical location of the key is more important than the key's host GUI semantics, such as for movement controls in a first-person game (German keyboard: Z key, UK keyboard: Y key, etc.)

MouseCursorType.doc: Current icon of the mouse cursor

CursorPosition.doc: Current position of the mouse cursor, relative to the window. Set to `Uninitialized` on startup (gets initialized on the first frame).

OutOfWindow.doc: The cursor is out of bound of the window. For security reasons, tracking the cursor is not permitted by the library

Uninitialized.doc: The cursor position is unknown because the app hasn't yet been started. This is the default value and should generally only be set on startup.

InWindow.doc: Cursor position relative to the top left corner of the window

mouse_cursor_type.doc: Current mouse cursor type, set to `None` if the cursor is hidden. (READWRITE)

cursor_position.doc: Current mouse cursor type, set to `None` if the cursor is hidden. (READWRITE)

is_cursor_locked.doc: Is the mouse cursor locked to the current window (important for applications like games)? (READWRITE)

left_down.doc: Is the left mouse button down? (READONLY)

right_down.doc: Is the right mouse button down? (READONLY)

middle_down.doc: Is the middle mouse button down? (READONLY)

scroll_x.doc: Scroll amount in pixels in the horizontal direction. Gets reset to 0 after every frame (READONLY)

scroll_y.doc: Scroll amount in pixels in the vertical direction. Gets reset to 0 after every frame (READONLY)

PlatformSpecificOptions.doc: Platform-specific window configuration, i.e. WM options that are not cross-platform

allow_drag_drop.doc: STARTUP ONLY: Whether the window should allow drag + drop operations (default: true)

window_icon.doc: STARTUP ONLY: Window icon (decoded bytes), usually 32x32x4 bytes large (`ICON_SMALL`), appears at the top right corner of the window

taskbar_icon.doc: READWRITE: Taskbar icon (decoded bytes), usually 256x256x4 bytes large (`ICON_BIG`). Can be changed in callbacks / at runtime.

parent_window.doc: READWRITE: Taskbar icon (decoded bytes), usually 256x256x4 bytes large (`ICON_BIG`). Can be changed in callbacks / at runtime.

WaylandTheme.doc: CSD theme of the window title / button controls

title_bar_font.doc: Font of the title bar, "sans-serif" by default

RendererType.doc: Renderer type of the current windows OpenGL context

StringPair.doc: Key-value pair, used for setting WM hints values specific to GNOME

x11_visual.doc: Which X11 visual to use for the window (unimplemented). Can only be set at window creation, can't be changed in callbacks

x11_screen.doc: Which screen to use when showing the window (unimplemented). Can only be set at window creation, can't be changed in callbacks

x11_wm_classes.doc: Build window with `WM_CLASS` hint; defaults to the name of the binary. Only relevant on X11. Can only be set at window creation, can't be changed in callbacks.

x11_override_redirect.doc: Build window with override-redirect flag; defaults to false. Only relevant on X11. Can only be set at window creation, can't be changed in callbacks.

x11_window_types.doc: Build window with `_NET_WM_WINDOW_TYPE` hint; defaults to `Normal`. Only relevant on X11. Can only be set at window creation, can't be changed in callbacks.

x11_gtk_theme_variant.doc: Build window with `_GTK_THEME_VARIANT` hint set to the specified value. Currently only relevant on X11. Can only be set at window creation, can't be changed in callbacks.

x11_resize_increments.doc: Build window with resize increment hint. Only implemented on X11. Can only be set at window creation, can't be changed in callbacks.

x11_base_size.doc: Build window with base size hint. Only implemented on X11. Can only be set at window creation, can't be changed in callbacks.

wayland_app_id.doc: Build window with a given application ID. It should match the `.desktop` file distributed with the program. Only relevant on Wayland. Can only be set at window creation, can't be changed in callbacks.

wayland_theme.doc: Window decoration of the window minimize / maximize / close buttons

request_user_attention.doc: Whether the window icon should blink to request the users attention.

window_icon.doc: Sets the window icon of the program

SlowFullScreen.doc:
- macOS: If the window is in windowed mode, transitions it slowly to fullscreen mode}
- other: Does the same as `FastFullScreen`.

FastFullScreen.doc: Window should immediately go into fullscreen mode (on macOS this is not the default behaviour).

SlowWindowed.doc:
- macOS: If the window is in fullscreen mode, transitions slowly back to windowed state.
- other: Does the same as `FastWindowed`.

FastWindowed.doc: If the window is in fullscreen mode, will immediately go back to windowed mode (on macOS this is not the default behaviour).

WindowTheme.doc: Window theme, set by the operating system or `WindowCreateOptions.theme` on startup

WindowPosition.doc: Position of the top left corner of the window relative to the top left of the monitor

Uninitialized.doc: Window position has not been initialized yet (default, only set on startup)

Initialized.doc: Initialized window position: modifying this value will move the window

ImePosition.doc: Position of the virtual keyboard necessary to insert CJK characters

TouchState.doc: Current state of touch devices / touch inputs

Monitor.doc: Information about a single (or many) monitors, useful for dock widgets

id.doc: Internal ID for the monitor, only useful at startup to specify which screen the window should be created on (unimplemented)

size.doc: Size of the monitor. Note that this does not say anything about DPI (i.e. the physical, real-world size of the monitor).

position.doc: Position relative to the top left of the "virtual" monitor size (if two or more monitors are connected, this area will usually be a union of all monitors)

scale_factor.doc: HiDPI scale factor of this monitor

video_modes.doc: List of video modes supported by this monitor

is_primary_monitor.doc: Whether this monitor is set as the primary monitor

VideoMode.doc: Describes a rendering configuration for a monitor

bit_depth.doc:
Returns the bit depth of this video mode, as in how many bits you have available per color. This is generally 24 bits or 32 bits on modern systems, depending on whether the alpha channel is counted or not.
Wayland: always returns 32.
iOS: always returns 32.

refresh_rate.doc: Returns the refresh rate of this video mode. Note: the returned refresh rate is an integer approximation, and you shouldn't rely on this value to be exact.

theme.doc: Current theme of the window (dark or light mode). Will emit a `ThemeChanged` event if it is changed in a callback.

size.doc: Size of the window + max width / max height: 800 x 600 by default

position.doc: The x and y position, or None to let the WM decide where to put the window (default)

flags.doc: Flags such as whether the window is minimized / maximized, fullscreen, etc.

debug_state.doc: Mostly used for debugging, shows WebRender-builtin graphs on the screen. Used for performance monitoring and displaying frame times (rendering-only).

keyboard_state.doc: Current keyboard state - NOTE: mutating this field (currently) does nothing (doesn't get synchronized with OS-level window)!

touch_state.doc: Current touch state, stores all states of currently connected touch input devices, pencils, tablets, etc. - NOTE: readonly field - mutating this field will not get synchronized with the OS

ime_position.doc: Sets location of IME candidate box in client area coordinates (relative to the top left of the window)

monitor.doc: Which monitor the window is currently residing on

platform_specific_options.doc: Window options that can only be set on a certain platform (`WindowsWindowOptions` / `LinuxWindowOptions` / `MacWindowOptions`).

renderer_options.doc: Whether this window has SRGB / vsync / hardware acceleration

background_color.doc: Color of the window background (can be transparent if necessary)

close_callback.doc: Callback to run before the window closes, if `DoNothing` is returned, window won't close

new.doc: Creates a new WindowState with default settings and a custom layout callback

default.doc: Creates a default WindowState with an empty layout callback - useful only if you use the Rust `WindowState { .. WindowState::default() }` intialization syntax.

callbacks.doc: Callback type definitions + struct definitions of `CallbackInfo`s

LayoutCallbackType.doc: Main callback to layout the UI. azul will only call this callback when necessary (usually when one of the callback or timer returns `RegenerateStyledDomForCurrentWindow`), however azul may also call this callback at any given time, so it should be performant. This is the main entry point for your app UI.

fn_args.doc: Useful information to contitionally return the structure of the DOM based on the width / height of the window

returns.doc: The styled DOM rendered from the application state

CallbackType.doc: Generic UI callback function pointer: called when the `EventFilter` is active

fn_args.doc: Reference counted opaque pointer to the data set in the `CallbackData` for the hit DOM node
Context struct to allow the callback to manipulate UI structures

returns.doc: Whether this callback has modified the application state in such a way that a full UI redraw is unavoidable. If any callback returns true, the `LayoutCallback` of the window will be called again to render the next frame.

get_hit_node.doc: Returns the `DomNodeId` of the element that the callback was attached to.

get_cursor_relative_to_viewport.doc: Returns the `LayoutPoint` of the cursor in the viewport (relative to the origin of the `Dom`). Set to `None` if the cursor is not in the current window.

get_cursor_relative_to_node.doc: Returns the `LayoutPoint` of the cursor in the viewport (relative to the origin of the `Dom`). Set to `None` if the cursor is not hovering over the current node.

get_window_state.doc: Returns a copy of the current windows `WindowState`.

get_keyboard_state.doc: Returns a copy of the internal `KeyboardState`. Same as `self.get_window_state().keyboard_state`

get_mouse_state.doc: Returns a copy of the internal `MouseState`. Same as `self.get_window_state().mouse_state`

get_current_window_handle.doc: Returns a copy of the current windows `RawWindowHandle`.

get_gl_context.doc: Returns a **reference-counted copy** of the current windows' `Gl` (context). You can use this to render OpenGL textures.

get_scroll_position.doc: Returns the x / y offset that this node has been scrolled to by the user or `None` if the node has not been scrolled.

get_dataset.doc: Returns the `dataset` property of the given Node or `None` if the node doesn't have a `dataset` property.

get_string_contents.doc: If the node is a `Text` node, returns a copy of the internal string contents.

get_inline_text.doc: If the node is a `Text` node, returns the layouted inline glyphs

get_parent.doc: Returns the parent `DomNodeId` of the given `DomNodeId`. Returns `None` on an invalid NodeId.

get_previous_sibling.doc: Returns the previous siblings `DomNodeId` of the given `DomNodeId`. Returns `None` on an invalid NodeId.

get_next_sibling.doc: Returns the next siblings `DomNodeId` of the given `DomNodeId`. Returns `None` on an invalid NodeId.

get_first_child.doc: Returns the next siblings `DomNodeId` of the given `DomNodeId`. Returns `None` on an invalid NodeId.

get_last_child.doc: Returns the next siblings `DomNodeId` of the given `DomNodeId`. Returns `None` on an invalid NodeId.

set_window_state.doc: Sets the new `WindowState` for the next frame. The window is updated after all callbacks are run.

set_focus.doc: Sets the new `FocusTarget` for the next frame. Note that this will emit a `On::FocusLost` and `On::FocusReceived` event, if the focused node has changed.

set_css_property.doc: Sets a `CssProperty` on a given node to its new value. If this property change affects the layout, this will automatically trigger a relayout and redraw of the screen.

set_scroll_position.doc: Sets the scroll position of the node

set_string_contents.doc: If the node is a `Text` node, overwrites the `Text` content with the new string, without requiring the entire UI to be rebuilt.

exchange_image.doc: If the node is an `Image`, exchanges the current image with a new source

exchange_image_mask.doc: If the node has an `ImageMask`, exchanges the current mask for the new mask

stop_propagation.doc: Stops the propagation of the current callback event type to the parent. Events are bubbled from the inside out (children first, then parents), this event stops the propagation of the event to the parent.

create_window.doc: Spawns a new window with the given `WindowCreateOptions`.

start_thread.doc: Starts a new `Thread` to the runtime. See the documentation for `Thread` for more information.

start_timer.doc: Adds a new `Timer` to the runtime. See the documentation for `Timer` for more information.

UpdateScreen.doc: Specifies if the screen should be updated after the callback function has returned

DoNothing.doc: The screen does not need to redraw after the callback has been called

RegenerateStyledDomForCurrentWindow.doc: After the callback is called, the screen needs to redraw (layout() function being called again)

RegenerateStyledDomForAllWindows.doc: After the callback is called, the layout() function needs to be called again for ALL windows

NodeId.doc: Index of a Node in the internal `NodeDataContainer`

inner.doc:
Index of the node into the vector.
**Note:** the `index` is offset by 1:

`0 = None`

`1 = Some(0)`

`2 = Some(1)`

DomId.doc: ID of a DOM - one window can contain multiple, nested DOMs (such as iframes)

inner.doc: Index of the dom into the `StyledDomVec`

DomNodeId.doc: Combination of node ID + DOM ID, both together can identify a node

get_logical_size.doc: Returns the size of the bounds in logical units

get_physical_size.doc: Returns the size of the bounds in physical units

get_hidpi_factor.doc: Returns the hidpi factor of the bounds

lines.doc: List of lines in this text, relative to the text origin

bounds.doc: Bounding rect of the union of all lines in this text (size of the text content in logical pixels)

font_size_px.doc: Font size in pixels used for layouting this text

last_word_index.doc: Index of the last `Word` in this text (- note that a `Word` can also be a `Space`, `Return` or `Tab`).

baseline_descender_px.doc: **NEGATIVE** descender of the text baseline (distance from baseline of the text to the bottom of the line)

hit_test.doc: Hit-tests the inline text, returns detailed information about which glyph / word / line, etc. the position (usually the mouse cursor) is currently over. Result may be empty (no hits) or contain more than one result (cursor is hovering over multiple overlapping glyphs at once).

words.doc: List of words in this line (includes tabs, return and spaces)

bounds.doc: Size and origin of the line, relative to the inline text origin (top left corner)

glyphs.doc: List of glyphs in this word

bounds.doc: origin and size of the word relative to the line origin (top left corner of the line)
origin and size of the glyph - note: origin relative to the word origin (top left corner of the word)

unicode_codepoint.doc: `Option<char>`: optional unicode codepoint of this glyph

glyph_index.doc: Index of the glyph in the font

unicode_codepoint.doc: `Option<char>`, if the glyph was a character (as opposed to a diacritic mark), contains the unicode codepoint of the character

hit_relative_to_inline_text.doc: Position of the hit relative to the top left corner of the inline text

hit_relative_to_line.doc: Position of the hit relative to the top left corner of the line

hit_relative_to_text_content.doc: Position of the hit relative to the top left corner of the word

hit_relative_to_glyph.doc: Position of the hit relative to the top left corner of the glyph

line_index_relative_to_text.doc: Index of the line in the text

word_index_relative_to_text.doc: Index of the word in the text (note: words include `Space`, `Tab` and `Return`)

text_content_index_relative_to_text.doc: Index of the text content in the text

glyph_index_relative_to_text.doc: Index of the hit glyph in the text (note: one glyph is not one character, glyphs include diacritic marks)

char_index_relative_to_text.doc: Index of the hit character (unicode codepoint) in the text.

word_index_relative_to_line.doc: Index of the hit word (note: includes `Tab`, `Space`, `Return`) in the hit line

text_content_index_relative_to_line.doc: Index of the hit text content ("word") in the hit line

glyph_index_relative_to_line.doc: Index of the hit glyph in the line (includes diacritic marks)

char_index_relative_to_line.doc: Index of the hit character (unicode codepoint) in the line

glyph_index_relative_to_word.doc: Index of the hit glyph in the word (includes diacritic marks)

char_index_relative_to_word.doc: Index of the hit character (unicode codepoint) in the word

FocusTarget.doc: Defines the keyboard input focus target

Id.doc: Set the focus by its DOM + Node ID

Path.doc: Set the focus by a CSS path

Previous.doc: Sets the focus to the previous focusable node in the DOM or `None` if this was the first focusable DOM node

Next.doc: Sets the focus to the next focusable node in the DOM or `None` if this was the last focusable DOM node

First.doc: Set the focus to the first focusable DOM or `None` if no nodes are focusable

Last.doc: Set the focus to the last focusable DOM or `None` if no nodes are focusable

FocusTargetPath.doc: CSS path to set the keyboard input focus

IFrameCallbackType.doc: For rendering large or infinite datasets such as tables or lists, azul uses `IFrameCallbacks` that allow the library user to only render the visible portion of DOM nodes, not the entire set. IFrames are rendered after the screen has been laid out, but before it gets composited. IFrames can be used recursively (i.e. iframes within iframes are possible). IFrames are re-rendered once the user scrolls to the bounds (see `IFrameCallbackReturn` on how to set the bounds) or the parent DOM was recreated.

fn_args.doc: An `IFrameCallback` can have some data passed along from the parent DOM - usually this would be struct containing the widget state
Similar to `LayoutInfo`, but carries an additional `bounds` field which has information about the size / current scroll position of the IFrame.

returns.doc: Contains the returned `StyledDom` as well as information about the initial scroll position of the new DOM plus scrollbar / overflow information

scroll_size.doc: How far the user has scrolled in the virtual scroll frame - useful to set the ``

scroll_offset.doc: How far the user has scrolled in the virtual scroll frame - useful to set the ``

virtual_scroll_size.doc: How far the user has scrolled in the virtual scroll frame - useful to set the ``

virtual_scroll_offset.doc: How far the user has scrolled in the virtual scroll frame - useful to set the ``

get_bounds.doc: Returns a copy of the internal `HidpiAdjustedBounds`

dom.doc: The DOM that is currently visible in the `HidpiAdjustedBounds`.

scroll_size.doc: The actual extent of the `dom` in pixels - usually larger than currently visible bounds. When the user scrolls to one of the edges of these bounds, this `IFrameCallback` will be called again, so you'd want to render some extra rows or columns so that the callback doesn't have to get called again on every single scrolled pixel.

scroll_offset.doc: Position that the `dom` should be scrolled to, relative to the `virtual_scroll_offset`.

virtual_scroll_size.doc: While the `scroll_size` is the currently rendered part of a larger scroll area, the virtual scroll size is the total size, even of non-rendered elements. For example, a table might show 30 - 40 rows and 10 columns, but the virtual size could be much larger. This setting only affects is the size of the scrollbar thumb.

virtual_scroll_offset.doc: Same as `virtual_scroll_offset`, but only affects the position of the scrollbar thumb

get_gl_context.doc: Returns a copy of the internal `Gl`

get_bounds.doc: Returns a copy of the internal `HidpiAdjustedBounds`

get_callback_node_id.doc: Returns the `DomNodeId` that this callback was called on

get_inline_text.doc: If the node is a `Text` node, returns the layouted inline glyphs

get_parent.doc: Returns the parent `DomNodeId` of the given `DomNodeId`. Returns `None` on an invalid NodeId.

get_previous_sibling.doc: Returns the previous siblings `DomNodeId` of the given `DomNodeId`. Returns `None` on an invalid NodeId.

get_next_sibling.doc: Returns the next siblings `DomNodeId` of the given `DomNodeId`. Returns `None` on an invalid NodeId.

get_first_child.doc: Returns the next siblings `DomNodeId` of the given `DomNodeId`. Returns `None` on an invalid NodeId.

get_last_child.doc: Returns the next siblings `DomNodeId` of the given `DomNodeId`. Returns `None` on an invalid NodeId.

_internal_len.doc: Length of Vec holding type-erased struct

_internal_layout_align.doc: Alignment of the type-erased struct (usually 0 or 8)

type_id.doc: TypeId that can uniquely identify the type of the struct, usually generated by the compiler (i.e. in Rust it would be `std::any::TypeId`)

type_name.doc: Optional, name of the type, usually compiler-generated (in Rust, `std::any::type_name<T>()`)

custom_destructor.doc: Function pointer to the destructor of `T`. Is called when the `num_copies` count of the `RefAny` reaches 0

RefAny.doc: RefAny is a reference-counted, type-erased pointer, which stores a reference to a struct. `RefAny` can be up- and downcasted (this usually done via generics and can't be expressed in the Rust API)

is_dead.doc: Field to check if the pointer is dead (TRUE BY DEFAULT!)

sharing_info.doc: Pointer to the reference count of this `RefAny`. Calling `.clone()` will not clone the data, only bump the reference count by 1. When the `num_copies` reaches 0, the destructor of this `RefAny` is called

uses_dark_theme.doc: Returns whether the window uses a dark or light theme - azul will register that the UI is dependent on theming and call the layout callback again when the theme changes

root.doc: Root node data - note that the global DOM root should be of `NodeType::Body`

children.doc: Child nodes of this root node

total_children.doc: Number of child nodes, including all child DOM trees

node_count.doc: Returns the number of nodes in the DOM, including all child DOM trees. Result is equal to `self.total_children + 1` (count of all child trees + the root node)

NodeData.doc: Represents one single DOM node (node type, classes, ids and callbacks are stored here)

node_type.doc: Stores the type of the node, i.e. `div`, `img`, `p`, etc.

dataset.doc: `dataset` attribute of the node, useful to store any UI-related data on the node itself

ids_and_classes.doc: Stores the ids of the node, i.e. `[#main, #something]`

callbacks.doc: Stores the callbacks of the node, i.e. `On::MouseUp` -> `Callback(my_button_click_handler)`

inline_css_props.doc: Override certain dynamic styling properties for this DOM node

clip_mask.doc: Optional clip mask for this DOM node

tab_index.doc: Whether this div can be focused, and if yes, in what default to `None` (not focusable). Note that without this, there can be no `On::FocusReceived` / `On::FocusLost` (equivalent to onfocus). For this reason, this is automatically set to `TabIndex::Auto` if a callback with `On::Focus*` is inserted

NodeType.doc: List of core DOM node types built-into by `azul`

Div.doc: Regular div with no particular type of data attached

Body.doc: Same as div, but only for the root node

Br.doc: Creates a break in an inline text layout

Label.doc:
Equivalent to the HTML `

` tag, a small label that can be (optionally) be selected by the user

Image.doc: Equivalent to the HTML `` tag, references an image via its ID, the ID is created by the `add_image()` function(s)

IFrame.doc: Callback that renders a DOM when invoked with a width / height after the layout of the parent DOM is done. Can be selected in CSS with the `"iframe"` selector.

GlTexture.doc: OpenGL texture, behaves same as a `<canvas>` / `img` node. Can be selected in CSS with the `"gltexture"` selector.

On.doc: When to call a callback action - `On::MouseOver`, `On::MouseOut`, etc.

MouseOver.doc: Mouse cursor is hovering over the element

MouseDown.doc: Mouse cursor has is over element and is pressed (not good for "click" events - use `MouseUp` instead)

LeftMouseDown.doc: (Specialization of `MouseDown`). Fires only if the left mouse button has been pressed while cursor was over the element

MiddleMouseDown.doc: (Specialization of `MouseDown`). Fires only if the middle mouse button has been pressed while cursor was over the element

RightMouseDown.doc: (Specialization of `MouseDown`). Fires only if the right mouse button has been pressed while cursor was over the element

MouseUp.doc: Mouse button has been released while cursor was over the element

LeftMouseUp.doc: (Specialization of `MouseUp`). Fires only if the left mouse button has been released while cursor was over the element

MiddleMouseUp.doc: (Specialization of `MouseUp`). Fires only if the middle mouse button has been released while cursor was over the element

RightMouseUp.doc: (Specialization of `MouseUp`). Fires only if the right mouse button has been released while cursor was over the element

MouseEnter.doc: Mouse cursor has entered the element

MouseLeave.doc: Mouse cursor has left the element

TextInput.doc: The window received a unicode character (also respects the system locale)

VirtualKeyDown.doc: Check `keyboard_state.current_char` to get the current pressed character

VirtualKeyUp.doc: A **virtual keycode** was pressed. Note: This is only the virtual keycode, not the actual char. If you want to get the character, use `TextInput` instead. **NOTE**: A virtual key does not have to map to a printable character. You can get all currently pressed virtual keycodes in the `keyboard_state.current_virtual_keycodes` and / or just the last keycode in the `keyboard_state.latest_virtual_keycode`.

Auto.doc: Automatic tab index, similar to simply setting `focusable = "true"` or `tabindex = 0`, (both have the effect of making the element focusable)

OverrideInParent.doc: Set the tab index in relation to its parent element (`tabindex = n`)

NoKeyboardFocus.doc: Elements can be focused in callbacks, but are not accessible via keyboard / tab navigation (`tabindex = -1` )

from_string.doc: Returns a CSS style parsed from a `String`

Stretch.doc: Default value. Lines stretch to take up the remaining space

Center.doc: Lines are packed toward the center of the flex container

Start.doc: Lines are packed toward the start of the flex container

End.doc: Lines are packed toward the end of the flex container

SpaceBetween.doc: Lines are evenly distributed in the flex container

SpaceAround.doc: Lines are evenly distributed in the flex container, with half-size spaces on either end

Stretch.doc: Items are stretched to fit the container

Center.doc: Items are positioned at the center of the container

FlexStart.doc: Items are positioned at the beginning of the container

FlexEnd.doc: Items are positioned at the end of the container

Start.doc: Default value. Items are positioned at the beginning of the container

End.doc: Items are positioned at the end of the container

Center.doc: Items are positioned at the center of the container

SpaceBetween.doc: Items are positioned with space between the lines

SpaceAround.doc: Items are positioned with space before, between, and after the lines

SpaceEvenly.doc: Items are distributed so that the spacing between any two adjacent alignment subjects, before the first alignment subject, and after the last alignment subject is the same

Scroll.doc: Always shows a scroll bar, overflows on scroll

Auto.doc: Does not show a scroll bar by default, only when text is overflowing

Hidden.doc: Never shows a scroll bar, simply clips text

Visible.doc: Doesn't show a scroll bar, simply overflows the text

ClosestSide.doc: The gradients ending shape meets the side of the box closest to its center (for circles) or meets both the vertical and horizontal sides closest to the center (for ellipses)

ClosestCorner.doc: The gradients ending shape is sized so that it exactly meets the closest corner of the box from its center

FarthestSide.doc: Similar to closest-side, except the ending shape is sized to meet the side of the box farthest from its center (or vertical and horizontal sides)

FarthestCorner.doc: The default value, the gradient's ending shape is sized so that it exactly meets the farthest corner of the box from its center

style.doc: DOM to CSS cascading and styling module

tag_id.doc: Optional hit-testing tag ID (NOTE: The tag ID has to be adjusted after the layout is done (to account for scroll tags))

new.doc: Styles a `Dom` with the given `Css`, returning the `StyledDom` - complexity `O(count(dom_nodes) * count(css_blocks))`: make sure that the `Dom` and the `Css` are as small as possible, use inline CSS if the performance isn't good enough

from_xml.doc: Returns a DOM loaded from an XML file

from_file.doc: Same as `from_xml`, but loads the file relative to the current directory

append.doc: Appends an already styled list of DOM nodes to the current `dom.root` - complexity `O(count(dom.dom_nodes))`

restyle.doc: Restyles an already styled DOM with a new CSS - overwrites old styles, but does not replace them, useful for implementing user styles that are applied on top of the existing application style

node_count.doc: Returns the number of nodes in the styled DOM

get_html_string.doc: Returns a HTML string that you can write to a file in order to debug the UI structure and debug potential cascading issues

format.doc: Format of this texture (rgba, brga, etc.)

flags.doc: Hints and flags for optimization purposes

gl_context.doc: A reference-counted pointer to the OpenGL context (so that the texture can be deleted in the destructor)

allocate_clip_mask.doc: Allocates an OpenGL texture of a given size with a single red channel (used for image masks)

draw_clip_mask.doc: Draws a vertex / index buffer (aka. `&TesselatedSvgNode`) to the texture

apply_fxaa.doc: Applies an FXAA filter to the texture

ptr.doc: Reference-counted pointer to the OpenGL context. Can not be copied between threads.

svg_shader.doc: OpenGL program ID of the SVG shader, compiled at startup

fxaa_shader.doc: OpenGL program ID of the FXAA shader, compiled at startup

renderer_type.doc: Extra flag to see whether we are using hardware OpenGL or software OpenGL

read_pixels_into_buffer.fn_body: gl.read_pixels_into_buffer(x, y, width, height, format, pixel_type, dst_buffer)

read_pixels.fn_body: gl.read_pixels(x, y, width, height, format, pixel_type)

read_pixels_into_pbo.fn_body: gl.read_pixels_into_pbo(x, y, width, height, format, pixel_type)

tex_image_2d.fn_body: gl.tex_image_2d(target, level, internal_format, width, height, border, format, ty, opt_data)

compressed_tex_image_2d.fn_body: gl.compressed_tex_image_2d(target, level, internal_format, width, height, border, data)

compressed_tex_sub_image_2d.fn_body: gl.compressed_tex_sub_image_2d(target, level, xoffset, yoffset, width, height, format, data)

tex_image_3d.fn_body: gl.tex_image_3d(target, level, internal_format, width, height, depth, border, format, ty, opt_data)

copy_tex_image_2d.fn_body: gl.copy_tex_image_2d(target, level, internal_format, x, y, width, height, border)

copy_tex_sub_image_2d.fn_body: gl.copy_tex_sub_image_2d(target, level, xoffset, yoffset, x, y, width, height)

copy_tex_sub_image_3d.fn_body: gl.copy_tex_sub_image_3d(target, level, xoffset, yoffset, zoffset, x, y, width, height)

tex_sub_image_2d.fn_body: gl.tex_sub_image_2d(target, level, xoffset, yoffset, width, height, format, ty, data)

tex_sub_image_2d_pbo.fn_body: gl.tex_sub_image_2d_pbo(target, level, xoffset, yoffset, width, height, format, ty, offset)

tex_sub_image_3d.fn_body: gl.tex_sub_image_3d(target, level, xoffset, yoffset, zoffset, width, height, depth, format, ty, data)

tex_sub_image_3d_pbo.fn_body: gl.tex_sub_image_3d_pbo(target, level, xoffset, yoffset, zoffset, width, height, depth, format, ty, offset)

tex_storage_3d.fn_body: gl.tex_storage_3d(target, levels, internal_format, width, height, depth)

copy_image_sub_data.fn_body: gl.copy_image_sub_data(src_name, src_target, src_level, src_x, src_y, src_z, dst_name, dst_target, dst_level, dst_x, dst_y, dst_z, src_width, src_height, src_depth)

invalidate_sub_framebuffer.fn_body: gl.invalidate_sub_framebuffer(target, attachments, xoffset, yoffset, width, height)

blit_framebuffer.fn_body: gl.blit_framebuffer(src_x0, src_y0, src_x1, src_y1, dst_x0, dst_y0, dst_x1, dst_y1, mask, filter)

vertex_attrib_pointer.fn_body: gl.vertex_attrib_pointer(index, size, type_, normalized, stride, offset)

copy_texture_chromium.fn_body: gl.copy_texture_chromium(source_id, source_level, dest_target, dest_id, dest_level, internal_format, dest_type, unpack_flip_y, unpack_premultiply_alpha, unpack_unmultiply_alpha)

copy_sub_texture_chromium.fn_body: gl.copy_sub_texture_chromium(source_id, source_level, dest_target, dest_id, dest_level, x_offset, y_offset, x, y, width, height, unpack_flip_y, unpack_premultiply_alpha, unpack_unmultiply_alpha)

copy_texture_3d_angle.fn_body: gl.copy_texture_3d_angle(source_id, source_level, dest_target, dest_id, dest_level, internal_format, dest_type, unpack_flip_y, unpack_premultiply_alpha, unpack_unmultiply_alpha)

copy_sub_texture_3d_angle.fn_body: gl.copy_sub_texture_3d_angle(source_id, source_level, dest_target, dest_id, dest_level, x_offset, y_offset, z_offset, x, y, z, width, height, depth, unpack_flip_y, unpack_premultiply_alpha, unpack_unmultiply_alpha)

GetActiveAttribReturn.doc: C-ABI stable reexport of `(i32, u32, AzString)`

GetActiveUniformReturn.doc: C-ABI stable reexport of `(i32, u32, AzString)`

is_opaque.doc: Whether this texture contains an alpha component

is_video_texture.doc: Optimization: use the compositor instead of OpenGL for energy efficiency

default.doc: Default texture flags (not opaque, not a video texture)

alpha_premultiplied.doc: Whether the image already has the alpha channel premultiplied

data_format.doc: Which data format (channels) the image uses

allocate_clip_mask.doc: Allocates a width * height, single-channel image with zeroed bytes

decode_image_bytes_any.doc: Decodes a RawImage from any supported image format - automatically guesses the format based on magic header

encode_bmp.doc: Encodes the RawImage in the BMP image format

encode_png.doc: Encodes the RawImage in the PNG image format

encode_jpeg.doc: Encodes the RawImage in the JPG image format

encode_tga.doc: Encodes the RawImage in the TGA image format

encode_pnm.doc: Encodes the RawImage in the PNM image format

encode_gif.doc: Encodes the RawImage in the GIF image format

encode_tiff.doc: Encodes the RawImage in the TIFF image format

Embedded.doc: Bytes of the image, encoded in PNG / JPG / etc. format

File.doc: References an (encoded!) image as a file from the file system that is loaded when necessary

Raw.doc: References a decoded (!) `RawImage` as the image source

InsufficientMemory.doc: Not enough memory available to perform the encoding operation

DimensionError.doc: Width x height x channels does not match the image data

InvalidData.doc: The data did not match the type of data necessary for encoding - for example, HDR can only encode image data of type `F32Vec`, not `U8Vec`.

InsufficientMemory.doc: Not enough memory available to perform the encoding operation

DimensionError.doc: Width x height x channels does not match the image data

UnsupportedImageFormat.doc: The image format is not supported

R8.doc: Bytes are in the R-unsinged-8bit format

R16.doc: Bytes are in the R-unsinged-16bit format

RG16.doc: Bytes are in the RG-unsinged-16bit format

BGRA8.doc: Bytes are in the BRGA-unsigned-8bit format

RGBAF32.doc: Bytes are in the RGBA-floating-point-32bit format

RG8.doc: Bytes are in the RG-unsigned-8bit format

RGBAI32.doc: Bytes are in the RGBA-signed-32bit format

RGBA8.doc: Bytes are in the RGBA-unsigned-8bit format

Embedded.doc: References a font from a font file that is embedded into the binary (`&'static [u8]`) or loaded from a `Vec<u8>`

File.doc: References a font from a file path, which is loaded when necessary

System.doc: References a font from from a system font identifier, such as `"Arial"` or `"Helvetica"`

postscript_id.doc: ID of the font, such as `Arial` or `Roboto`

font_data.doc: Bytes are the bytes of the font file

load_glyph_outlines.doc: Whether the glyph outlines should be loaded - must be explicitly enabled in order to save RAM

postscript_id.doc: ID of the font, such as `Arial` or `Roboto`

file_path.doc: Path to the file of the font

load_glyph_outlines.doc: Whether the glyph outlines should be loaded - must be explicitly enabled in order to save RAM

postscript_id.doc: ID of the font, such as `Arial` or `Roboto`

load_glyph_outlines.doc: Whether the glyph outlines should be loaded - must be explicitly enabled in order to save RAM

empty.doc: Returns an empty buffer vertices / indices

from_nodes.doc: Creates a new TesselatedSvgNode by joining all the given nodes together into one array and inserting a `GL_RESTART_INDEX` (`u32::MAX`) into the indices (so that the resulting buffer can be drawn in one draw call).

relative_image_path.doc: SVG image path. Used to resolve relative image paths.

dpi.doc: Target DPI. Impact units conversion. Default: 96.0

default_font_family.doc: Default font family. Will be used when no font-family attribute is set in the SVG. Default: Times New Roman

font_size.doc: A default font size. Will be used when no font-size attribute is set in the SVG. Default: 12

languages.doc: A list of languages. Will be used to resolve a systemLanguage conditional attribute. Format: en, en-US. Default: [en]

shape_rendering.doc: Specifies the default shape rendering method. Will be used when an SVG element's shape-rendering property is set to auto. Default: GeometricPrecision

text_rendering.doc: Specifies the default text rendering method. Will be used when an SVG element's text-rendering property is set to auto. Default: OptimizeLegibility

image_rendering.doc: Specifies the default image rendering method. Will be used when an SVG element's image-rendering property is set to auto. Default: OptimizeQuality

keep_named_groups.doc: Keep named groups. If set to true, all non-empty groups with id attribute will not be removed. Default: false

fontdb.doc: When empty, text elements will be skipped. Default: `System`

use_single_quote.doc: Whether to use single or double quotes when formatting the SVG string

indent.doc: How to indent SVG nodes when formatting SVG

attributes_indent.doc: How to indent the attributes when formatting SVG

Winding.doc: Use the winding order to determine the filled area

EvenOdd.doc: Use the even / odd rule to determine the filled area

line_join.doc: How to tesselate edges in a path, default value = `Miter`

miter_limit.doc: Limit for caps on path edges if line_join is set to `Miter`. Must be greater than or equal to 1px. Default value = 1.0

tolerance.doc: Maximum allowed distance between path points when tesselating curves. Default value = 0.1 (px)

fill_rule.doc: Fill rule to use when painting the polygon

transform.doc: Scaling / rotation / etc. transform to apply to the polygon before painting. NOTE: currently only implemented on CPU renderer

anti_alias.doc: Whether the polygon is intended to be rendered anti-aliased

high_quality_aa.doc: Whether anti-aliasing should use the fast approximate solution (true) or the high-quality slow one (false). Default: false

start_cap.doc: What cap to use at the start of each sub-path, default value = `Butt`

end_cap.doc: What cap to use at the end of each sub-path, default value = `Butt`

line_join.doc: How to tesselate edges in a path, default value = `Miter`

dash_pattern.doc: Optional dash pattern for the stroke, default value = `None`

line_width.doc: Width of the line in px. Default value = 1.09 (px)

miter_limit.doc: Limit for caps on path edges if line_join is set to `Miter`. Must be greater than or equal to 1.0 (px). Default value = 1.0

tolerance.doc: Maximum allowed distance between path points when tesselating curves. Default value = 0.1 (px)

apply_line_width.doc: When set to false, the generated vertices will all be positioned in the center. The width can be applied later on (eg in a vertex shader) by adding the vertex normal multiplied by the line with to each vertex position. Default value = `false`

transform.doc: Scaling / rotation / etc. transform to apply to the polygon before painting. NOTE: currently only implemented on CPU renderer

anti_alias.doc: Whether the polygon is intended to be rendered anti-aliased

high_quality_aa.doc: Whether anti-aliasing should use the fast approximate solution (true) or the high-quality slow one (false). Default: false

root.doc: Root node(s) of the XML document

from_str.doc: Parses an XML document with one or more root nodes

tag.doc:
Tag type of the node, i.e. the `p` part of `

Hello World

`

attributes.doc:
Attributes of the node, i.e. the `{ key: id, value: test }` part of `

Hello World

`

children.doc:
Attributes of the node, i.e. the `World` part of `

Hello World

`

text.doc:
Text content of the node, i.e. the `Hello` part of `

Hello

`

fs.doc: Filesystem / file input and output module

open.doc: Opens a file at the given path. If the file exists, replaces it with a new file

create.doc: Creates a file at the given path. If the file exists, replaces it with a new file

read_to_string.doc: Reads the file to a UTF8-encoded String, returns None if the file can't be decoded correctly

read_to_bytes.doc: Reads the file as bytes, returns None if the file can't be decoded correctly

write_string.doc: Writes a string to the file, synchronizes the results before returning

write_bytes.doc: Writes some bytes to the file, synchronizes the results before returning

dialog.doc: Interface for system file selection dialogs / popup message boxes, etc.

ok.doc: Opens an informational message box with only an "OK" button

ok_cancel.doc: Opens a ok / cancel message box. Blocks the current thread.

yes_no.doc: Opens a yes / no message box. Blocks the current thread.

MsgBoxYesNo.doc: Value returned from a yes / no message box

MsgBoxOkCancel.doc: Value returned from an ok / cancel message box

_reserved.doc: Non-existent field for ABI stability. Do not use.

select_file.doc: Select a single file using the system-native file picker. Blocks the current thread.

returns.doc: The path that the user wants to open, `None` if the user has cancelled or closed the dialog

select_multiple_files.doc: Select multiple files using the system-native file picker. Blocks the current thread.

returns.doc: The path(s) that the user wants to open, `None` if the user has cancelled or closed the dialog

select_folder.doc: Open a dialog prompting the user to select a directory to open. Blocks the current thread.

returns.doc: The folder that the user wants to open, `None` if the user has cancelled or closed the dialog

save_file.doc: Open a dialog prompting the user to save a file. Blocks the current thread.

returns.doc: The path that the user wants to save the file to, `None` if the user has cancelled or closed the dialog

document_types.doc: A list of document types, such as ["doc", "docx", "png"]

open.doc: Opens a system-native color picker dialog

task.doc: Asyncronous timers / task / thread handlers for easy async loading

data.doc: Stores some timer-specific data (usually animation data)

created.doc: Stores when the timer was created (usually acquired by `Instant::now()`)

last_run.doc: When the timer was last called (`None` only when the timer hasn't been called yet)

run_count.doc: How often the timer was run already

delay.doc: If the timer shouldn't start instantly, but rather be delayed by a certain duration

interval.doc: How frequently the timer should run, i.e. set this to `Some(Duration::from_millis(16))` to run the timer every 16ms. If this value is set to `None`, (the default), the timer will execute the timer as-fast-as-possible (i.e. at a faster framerate than the framework itself) - which might be  performance intensive.

timeout.doc: When to stop the timer (for example, you can stop the execution after 5s using `Some(Duration::from_secs(5))`).

callback.doc: Callback to be called for this timer

TerminateTimer.doc: Should a timer terminate or not - used to remove active timers

Terminate.doc: Remove the timer from the list of active timers

Continue.doc: Do nothing and let the timers continue to run

GetSystemTimeFn.doc: Get the current system time, equivalent to `std::time::Instant::now()`, except it also works on systems that work with "ticks" instead of timers

CheckThreadFinishedFn.doc: Function called to check if the thread has finished

LibrarySendThreadMsgFn.doc: Function to send a message to the thread

LibraryReceiveThreadMsgFn.doc: Function to receive a message from the thread

ThreadRecvFn.doc: Function that the running `Thread` can call to receive messages from the main UI thread

ThreadSendFn.doc: Function that the running `Thread` can call to receive messages from the main UI thread

format.doc: Creates a dynamically formatted String from a fomat string + named arguments

trim.doc: Trims whitespace from the start / end of the string

as_refstr.doc: Returns a reference to the string - NOTE: the returned value is a reference to `self`, you MUST NOT drop the `String` object that the `Refstr` references

as_ref_vec.doc: Returns the `TesselatedSvgNodeVec` as a non-owning slice, NOTE: The `U8Vec` that this slice was borrowed from MUST NOT be deleted before the `U8VecRef`
Returns the `U8Vec` as a non-owning slice, NOTE: The `U8Vec` that this slice was borrowed from MUST NOT be deleted before the `U8VecRef`

OptionChar.doc: Option<char> but the char is a u32, for C FFI stability reasons

error.doc: Definition of error and `Result<T, E>`  types
